outcomeTitle: Use mathematical operational skills linked to expressions and formulae
assessmentStandards: [{"code":"AS1.1","desc":"Applying algebraic skills to manipulating expressions and working with formulae","skills_list":["Using the distributive law in an expression with a numerical common factor to produce a sum of terms","Factorising a sum of terms with a numerical common factor","Simplifying an expression which has more than one variable","Evaluating an expression or a formulae which has more than one variable","Extending a straightforward number or diagrammatic pattern and determining its formula","Calculating the gradient of a straight line from horizontal and vertical distances"]},{"code":"AS1.2","desc":"Applying geometric skills to circumference, area and volume","skills_list":["Calculating the circumference and area of a circle","Calculating the area of a parallelogram, kite, trapezium","Investigating the surface of a prism (know face, vertex, edge; draw nets; calculate surface area)","Calculating the volume of a prism (triangular prism, cylinder, other prisms given the area of the base)","Using rotational symmetry (with straightforward shapes)"]},{"code":"AS1.3","desc":"Applying statistical skills to representing and analysing data and to probability","skills_list":["Constructing a frequency table with class intervals from raw data (using ungrouped data)","Determining statistics of a data set (mean, median, mode, range)","Interpreting calculated statistics (using mean, median, mode, range to compare data sets)","Representing raw data in a pie chart (calculation of sector angles for given categories)","Using probability (calculation of probability; interpret probability in the context of risk)"]}]
teacherGuidance:
**AS1.1**: Applying algebraic skills to manipulating expressions and working with formulae
  Skills: Using the distributive law in an expression with a numerical common factor to produce a sum of terms, Factorising a sum of terms with a numerical common factor, Simplifying an expression which has more than one variable, Evaluating an expression or a formulae which has more than one variable, Extending a straightforward number or diagrammatic pattern and determining its formula, Calculating the gradient of a straight line from horizontal and vertical distances

**AS1.2**: Applying geometric skills to circumference, area and volume
  Skills: Calculating the circumference and area of a circle, Calculating the area of a parallelogram, kite, trapezium, Investigating the surface of a prism (know face, vertex, edge; draw nets; calculate surface area), Calculating the volume of a prism (triangular prism, cylinder, other prisms given the area of the base), Using rotational symmetry (with straightforward shapes)

**AS1.3**: Applying statistical skills to representing and analysing data and to probability

outcomeTitle: Use mathematical operational skills linked to relationships
assessmentStandards: [{"code":"AS1.1","desc":"Applying algebraic skills to linear equations","skills_list":["Drawing and recognising a graph of a linear equation (draw a graph for values of x; for y=mx+c, know the meaning of m and c; recognise and use y=a, x=b)","Solving linear equations (ax+b=c; ax+b=cx+d where a, b, c, d are integers)","Changing the subject of a formula (e.g., G=x+a to x; h=v/n to v; E=3w-k to w)"]},{"code":"AS1.2","desc":"Applying geometric skills to sides and angles of shapes","skills_list":["Using Pythagoras' theorem (given measurements, given coordinates)","Using a fractional scale factor to enlarge or reduce a shape (non-regular rectilinear shape)","Using parallel lines, symmetry and circle properties to calculate angles (combination of angle properties associated with: intersecting and parallel lines, triangles and quadrilaterals; circles: angle in a semi-circle, relationship between tangent and radius)"]},{"code":"AS1.3","desc":"Applying trigonometric skills to right angled triangles","skills_list":["Calculating a side in a right-angled triangle (given a side and an angle)","Calculating an angle in a right-angled triangle (given two sides)"]},{"code":"AS1.4","desc":"Applying statistical skills to representing data","skills_list":["Constructing a scattergraph (given a set of data)","Drawing and applying a best-fitting straight line (line should have roughly the same number of data points on either side; use the line of best fit to estimate one variable, given the other)"]}]
teacherGuidance:
**AS1.1**: Applying algebraic skills to linear equations
  Skills: Drawing and recognising a graph of a linear equation (draw a graph for values of x; for y=mx+c, know the meaning of m and c; recognise and use y=a, x=b), Solving linear equations (ax+b=c; ax+b=cx+d where a, b, c, d are integers), Changing the subject of a formula (e.g., G=x+a to x; h=v/n to v; E=3w-k to w)

**AS1.2**: Applying geometric skills to sides and angles of shapes
  Skills: Using Pythagoras' theorem (given measurements, given coordinates), Using a fractional scale factor to enlarge or reduce a shape (non-regular rectilinear shape), Using parallel lines, symmetry and circle properties to calculate angles (combination of angle properties associated with: intersecting and parallel lines, triangles and quadrilaterals; circles: angle in a semi-circle, relationship between tangent and radius)

**AS1.3**: Applying trigonometric skills to right angled triangles
  Skills: Calculating a side in a right-angled triangle (given a side and an angle), Calculating an angle in a right-angled triangle (given two sides)

**AS1.4**: Applying statistical skills to representing data
  Skills: Constructing a scattergraph (given a set of data), Drawing and applying a best-fitting straight line (line should have roughly the same number of data points on either side; use the line of best fit to estimate one variable, given the other)

outcomeTitle: Use numerical skills to solve given, straightforward real-life problems involving money/time/measurement
assessmentStandards: [{"code":"AS1.1","desc":"Selecting and using appropriate numerical notation and units","skills_list":["Numerical notation should include: =, +, -, ×, ÷, /, <, >, (), %, decimal point","Units should include: money (pounds and pence); time (months, weeks, days, hours, minutes, seconds); measurement of length (millimetre, centimetre, metre, kilometre, mile); weight (gram, kilogram); volume (millilitre, litre) and temperature (Celsius or Fahrenheit)"]},{"code":"AS1.2","desc":"Selecting and carrying out calculations","skills_list":["Add and subtract whole numbers including negative numbers","Multiply whole numbers of any size, with up to four-digit whole numbers","Divide whole numbers of any size, by a single digit whole number or by 10 or 100","Round answers to the nearest significant figure or two decimal places","Find simple percentages and fractions of shapes and quantities, eg 50%, 10%, 20%, 25%, 33⅓%; ½, ⅓, ¼, ⅒, ⅙","Calculate percentage increase and decrease","Convert equivalences between common fractions, decimals and percentages","Calculate rate: eg miles per hour or number of texts per month","Calculate distance given speed and time","Calculate time intervals using the 12- and 24-hour clock","Calculate volume (cube and cuboid), area (rectangle and square) and perimeter (shapes with straight lines)","Calculate ratio and direct proportion"]},{"code":"AS1.3","desc":"Reading measurements using a straightforward scale on an instrument","skills_list":["Use measuring instruments with straightforward scales to measure length, weight, volume and temperature","Read scales to the nearest marked, unnumbered division with a functional degree of accuracy"]},{"code":"AS1.4","desc":"Interpreting the measurements and the results of calculations to make decisions","skills_list":["Use appropriate checking methods, eg check sums and estimation","Interpret results of measurements involving time, length, weight, volume and temperature","Recognise the inter-relationship between units in the same family, eg mm/cm, cm/m, g/kg, and ml/l","Use vocabulary associated with measurement to make comparisons for length, weight, volume and temperature"]},{"code":"AS1.5","desc":"Explaining decisions based on the results of measurements or calculations","skills_list":["Give reasons for decisions based on the results of calculations"]}]
teacherGuidance:
**AS1.1**: Selecting and using appropriate numerical notation and units
  Skills: Numerical notation should include: =, +, -, ×, ÷, /, <, >, (), %, decimal point, Units should include: money (pounds and pence); time (months, weeks, days, hours, minutes, seconds); measurement of length (millimetre, centimetre, metre, kilometre, mile); weight (gram, kilogram); volume (millilitre, litre) and temperature (Celsius or Fahrenheit)

**AS1.2**: Selecting and carrying out calculations
  Skills: Add and subtract whole numbers including negative numbers, Multiply whole numbers of any size, with up to four-digit whole numbers, Divide whole numbers of any size, by a single digit whole number or by 10 or 100, Round answers to the nearest significant figure or two decimal places, Find simple percentages and fractions of shapes and quantities, eg 50%, 10%, 20%, 25%, 33⅓%; ½, ⅓, ¼, ⅒, ⅙, Calculate percentage increase and decrease, Convert equivalences between common fractions, decimals and percentages, Calculate rate: eg miles per hour or number of texts per month, Calculate distance given speed and time, Calculate time intervals using the 12- and 24-hour clock, Calculate volume (cube and cuboid), area (rectangle and square) and perimeter (shapes with straight lines), Calculate ratio and direct proportion

**AS1.3**: Reading measurements using a straightforward scale on an instrument
  Skills: Use measuring instruments with straightforward scales to measure length, weight, volume and temperature, Read scales to the nearest marked, unnumbered division with a functional degree of accuracy

**AS1.4**: Interpreting the measurements and the results of calculations to make decisions
  Skills: Use appropriate checking methods, eg check sums and estimation, Interpret results of measurements involving time, length, weight, volume and temperature, Recognise the inter-relationship between units in the same family, eg mm/cm, cm/m, g/kg, and ml/l, Use vocabulary associated with measurement to make comparisons for length, weight, volume and temperature

**AS1.5**: Explaining decisions based on the results of measurements or calculations
  Skills: Give reasons for decisions based on the results of calculations

assessmentStandards: [{"code":"AS2.1","desc":"Extracting and interpreting data from at least two different straightforward graphical forms","skills_list":["Straightforward graphical forms should include: a table with at least four categories of information; a chart where the values are given or where the scale is obvious, eg pie; a graph where the scale is obvious, eg bar, pie, scatter or line graph; a diagram, eg stem and leaf, map or plan"]},{"code":"AS2.2","desc":"Making and explaining decisions based on the interpretation of data from straightforward graphical forms","skills_list":["Make decisions based on observations of patterns and trends in data","Make decisions based on calculations involving data","Make decisions based on reading scales in straightforward graphical forms","Offer reasons for the decisions made based on the interpretation of data"]},{"code":"AS2.3","desc":"Making and explaining decisions based on probability","skills_list":["Recognise patterns and trends and use these to state the probability of an event happening","Make predictions and use these predictions to make decisions"]}]
teacherGuidance:

  Skills: Straightforward graphical forms should include: a table with at least four categories of information; a chart where the values are given or where the scale is obvious, eg pie; a graph where the scale is obvious, eg bar, pie, scatter or line graph; a diagram, eg stem and leaf, map or plan

**AS2.3**: Making and explaining decisions based on probability
  Skills: Recognise patterns and trends and use these to state the probability of an event happening, Make predictions and use these predictions to make decisions
